displaytitle: Anacreon with his Mistress and the Young Bathyllos
medium: Pen and black ink and grey wash, heightened with white gouache
creditline: Museum purchase, with funds given by several donors

titles.title: Anacreon with his Mistress and the Young Bathyllos

makers.displaymaker: formerly attributed to Pierre Narcisse Guérin, French, 1774 - 1833

texts.textentryhtml: Academically trained artists such as Garnier epitomized the taste for classical subjects predominant in European art and design between the years 1750 and 1830. These artists sought to precisely depict an idealized antique world as they imagined it from classical literature and recent archaeological discoveries. In the Salon of 1793, Garnier exhibited a sexually charged painting, derived from an episode in the Epodes of Horace, in which the Greek poet Anacreon falls in love with a beautiful male youth. In this finished drawing, the artist recorded his composition in tones of black and white.

bibliography.boilertext: Barbara T. Ross, "Notes on selected French old master drawings from the permanent collection," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 42, no. 1 (1983): p. 4-42.
